issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The described issue is not actually a problem - it is as designed.
resolution.name: Not A Problem

versions.description: Maintenance release with new AMQP support and smaller modules

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
I just tried updating to 2.8.0 using the new activemq-broker and activemq-client modules instead of the previous activemq-core and get a KahaDB exception (see below).  Using activemq-all works.  Just naively trying add the latest kahadb to my pom didn't correct the issue.

I'm making the following calls:
ActiveMQConnectionFactory connectionFactory = new ActiveMQConnectionFactory("vm://localhost");

connection = connectionFactory.createConnection();
connection.start();
session = connection.createSession(false, Session.AUTO_ACKNOWLEDGE);


364 [main] ERROR org.apache.activemq.broker.BrokerService - Failed to start Apache ActiveMQ (localhost, null). Reason:

comments.body: Thanks, that worked.  I would therefore propose activemq-kahadb-store be a maven dependency of broker.
-all gives u that, with the current default store and well used transports. The idea is that you choose your store module (kahadb, jdbc, leveldb) if you don't go down the -all route.
If not using activemq-all you need to add the activemq-kahadb-store dependency to you project as that's where the KahaDB persistence adapter is located.
